Name: n-olefins production | n-olefins | EN15804GD, U
Category: C:Manufacturing/20:Manufacture of chemicals and chemical products/201:Manufacture of basic chemicals, fertilizers and nitrogen compounds, plastics/2011:Manufacture of basic chemicals
Description: n-Olefins in the context of the detergents production means higher (C10 to C16) olefins, produced either by dehydrogenation of the corresponding n-paraffins or by ethylene oligomerization. ;Dehydrogenation of n-paraffins: a combination of two processes – Pacol (paraffin catalyst olefin) and Olex (olefin extraction) – is most often used. The first step, at a temperature of 450 to 510°C and a pressure of 0.3 Mpa, uses a hydrogen : carbon ratio of 9:1. The whole process uses a platinum catalyst (0.8 wt%) on alumina, activated by adding lithium, arsenic or germanium. The resulting paraffin-olefin mixture is then separated in the second process, using molecular sieves, absorbing olefins more strongely.;;;Ethylene oligomerization: Two different methods are mainly used for the production of n-olefins out of ethylene: the SHOP (Shell’s higher olefin process) or the Ziegler reaction.  ;For the dataset it is assumed based on literature sources that both ways have a similar yield and the relation n-paraffins to ethylene for the synthesis of n-olefins is of 35% to 65%. ;References:;Behr (2000)
